text: Kimberly, they'll be leaving bright and early. Actually, it'll be dark when you leave tomorrow morning, but we use the expression bright and early. I found out she died yesterday, and I found out today, and so I'm assuming on Saturday, I'm gonna be making a trip up to New Jersey to preach a funeral for my great aunt, and if you would pray for that, I would appreciate it, and we got a number of family members that are not saved, a number of family members that come together for funerals, as perhaps many of you have that same situation, and I'll preach the gospel. She was a lady that I believe, through conversation with her, she knew the Lord as her Savior, so we're thankful for that, but I know we have a lot of family members that do not know the Lord as their Savior, and so we certainly would appreciate your prayers with regard to that. First Thessalonians chapter number five this evening. First Thessalonians chapter number five, and be looking at verse number 15. Of course, over the last several weeks, this is actually lesson number eight, as we have studied through this very concise, yet applicable instruction that God gives to the church at Thessalonica at the end of this particular letter. Again, the end of chapter number three of the second letter, we find another list of bullet point instruction, if you will, and we've gone through each Wednesday evening looking at these pieces of instruction as we've sought to be able to apply this truth in our lives. The Christian life, we know, must be lived through the power of the Holy Spirit. You try to live the Christian life in your own flesh, your own power, it's gonna be frustrating, and this is the truth that God did not design that we would live the Christian life in our own flesh, in our own power. Remember, Jesus said in John 15, without me, ye can do nothing, and it's very interesting how often we find in the scriptures that God instructs us to not do certain things that would be natural to do in our flesh, and so he instructs us not to do those things, and then there are things that God instructs us to do that naturally we don't wanna do in our flesh, and why do we find those instructions? Well, because God says this is what pleases me, and so he instructs us accordingly, and then we understand that we must live in dependence on the Lord and the power of the Holy Spirit in order to do the work that God has called us to do. We must die to self, we must walk in the Spirit. It is imperative that we are emptied of self so that we can be filled with the Holy Spirit of God. You're not gonna be, we understand the truth, the teaching that we are indwelled with the Spirit of God at the moment of salvation, but understand, though we received all of the Holy Spirit at the moment of salvation that we'll ever have, the reality is that he doesn't have all of you or all of me on any given day, and so we must yield ourselves, we must be dead to self, emptied of self so that we can be filled with the Holy Spirit. We find here in 1 Thessalonians 5 and verse 15, notice the Bible says this. See that none render evil for evil unto any man, but ever follow that which is good, both among yourselves and to all men. If it be possible, as much as lieth in you, live peaceably with all men. Notice 19, dearly beloved, avenge not yourselves, but rather give place unto wrath, for it is written, vengeance is mine, I will repay, saith the Lord. Therefore, if thine enemy hunger, feed him. If he thirst, give him drink. For in so doing, thou shalt heap coals of fire on his head. Verse 21, be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good. This is not natural. It's not natural for your flesh or for my flesh, but we find that the Lord gives us this instruction, and as he gives us this instruction, it reveals to us how desperately we need the Lord in order to fulfill the instruction that he's provided. Turn over very quickly, if you will, to Proverbs 24, and look at verse number 29 with me, Proverbs 24 and verse number 29. The Bible says here, say not, I will do so to him as he hath done to me. That's not how God has instructed believers to live, and we find in this portion of scripture, I'm gonna use a title from the verse over in Romans chapter number 12, verse 21, the title overcome evil with good. Overcome evil with good. And here, the Lord, the Holy Spirit of God is the author of scripture. He says, see that none render evil for evil, notice, unto any man. It's a different, it doesn't have anything to do with this lesson this evening, but we see that the word is translated that way. And so the idea as we look at verse 15, why is it that we need to be careful? Why is it that we need to take heed? Well, I believe the reason is because your flesh desires to react in a certain way. I'm thankful that we serve a gracious God and that we have received grace and then we too are to give grace, we're to be gracious. In 1 Peter 2 and verse 21, notice what the Bible says, for even here unto were ye called. Because Christ also suffered for us. Notice what it says, leaving us an example that ye should follow his steps. We find that it says this in verse 23, who when he was reviled, reviled not again. When he suffered he threatened not, but committed himself to him that judgeth righteously. You know so often if we're not careful as we live in this world and we deal with individuals and we have interactions and we deal with hardships and difficulties, we can be tempted to respond in the flesh because we want to get even, we want to get back this idea maybe if you could look at this portion of scripture with the thought of one that would be seeking revenge. And yet we find that the Holy Spirit of God so often as he's speaking to his people in the New Testament, as he's giving us the word of God, he's writing to us and he's giving us instruction that at the face value we look at it and say how in the world could I do this? Well you can't apart from the power of the Holy Spirit of God. And Christians are to be different. They don't see any difference in our behavior.
